column1: 02-682||"VERIZON COMMUNICATIONS INC. v. LAW OFFICES OF CURTIS V. TRINKO
certiorari to the united states court of appeals for the second circuit
The Telecommunications Act of 1996 imposes upon an incumbent local exchange carrier (LEC) the obligation to share its telephone network with competitors
column3: including the duty to provide access to individual network elements on an unbundled basis
column5: so-called competitive LECs
column6: combine and resell these unbundled network elements (UNEs).  Petitioner Verizon Communications Inc.
column7: the incumbent LEC in New York State
column8: has signed interconnection agreements with rivals such as AT&T
column9: as 252 obliges it to do
column10: detailing the terms on which it will make its network elements available.  Part of Verizons 251(c)(3) UNE obligation is the provision of access to operations support systems (OSS)
column11: without which a rival cannot fill its customers orders.  Verizons interconnection agreement
column12: approved by the New York Public Service Commission (PSC)
column13: and its authorization to provide long-distance service
column14: approved by the Federal Communications Commission (FCC)
column15: each specified the mechanics by which its OSS obligation would be met.  When competitive LECs complained that Verizon was violating that obligation
column16: the PSC and FCC opened parallel investigations
column17: which led to the imposition of financial penalties
column18: remediation measures
column19: and additional reporting requirements on Verizon.  Respondent
column20: a local telephone service customer of AT&T
column21: then filed this class action alleging
column22: inter alia
column23: that Verizon had filled rivals orders on a discriminatory basis as part of an anticompetitive scheme to discourage customers from becoming or remaining customers of competitive LECs in violation of 2 of the Sherman Act
column24: 15 U. S.C. 2.  The District Court dismissed the complaint
column25: concluding that respondents allegations of deficient assistance to rivals failed to satisfy 2s requirements.  The Second Circuit reinstated the antitrust claim.

column1: Held:Respondents complaint alleging breach of an incumbent LECs 1996 Act duty to share its network with competitors does not state a claim under 2 of the Sherman Act.  Pp.516.
(a)The 1996 Act has no effect upon the application of traditional antitrust principles.  Its saving clausewhich provides that nothing in this Act  shall be construed to modify
column3: or supersede the applicability of any of the antitrust laws
column5: notepreserves claims that satisfy established antitrust standards
column6: but does not create new claims that go beyond those standards.  Pp.57.

column1: (b)The activity of which respondent complains does not violate pre-existing antitrust standards.  The leading case imposing 2 liability for refusal to deal with competitors is Aspen Skiing Co. v. Aspen Highlands Skiing Corp.
column3: in which the Court concluded that the defendants termination of a voluntary agreement with the plaintiff suggested a willingness to forsake short-term profits to achieve an anticompetitive end.  Aspen is at or near the outer boundary of 2 liability
column4: and the present case does not fit within the limited exception it recognized.  Because the complaint does not allege that Verizon ever engaged in a voluntary course of dealing with its rivals
column5: its prior conduct sheds no light upon whether its lapses from the legally compelled dealing were anticompetitive.  Moreover
column6: the Aspen defendant turned down its competitors proposal to sell at its own retail price
column7: suggesting a calculation that its future monopoly retail price would be higher
column8: whereas Verizons reluctance to interconnect at the cost-based rate of compensation available under 251(c)(3) is uninformative.  More fundamentally
column9: the Aspen defendant refused to provide its competitor with a product it already sold at retail
column10: whereas here the unbundled elements offered pursuant to 251(c)(3) are not available to the public
column11: but are provided to rivals under compulsion and at considerable expense.  The Courts conclusion would not change even if it considered to be established law the essential facilities doctrine crafted by some lower courts.  The indispensable requirement for invoking that doctrine is the unavailability of access to the essential facilities; where access exists
column12: as it does here by virtue of the 1996 Act
column13: the doctrine serves no purpose.  Pp.711.

column1: (c)Traditional antitrust principles do not justify adding the present case to the few existing exceptions from the proposition that there is no duty to aid competitors.  Antitrust analysis must always be attuned to the particular structure and circumstances of the industry at issue.  When there exists a regulatory structure designed to deter and remedy anticompetitive harm
column2: the additional benefit to competition provided by antitrust enforcement will tend to be small
column3: and it will be less plausible that the antitrust laws contemplate such additional scrutiny.  Here Verizon was subject to oversight by the FCC and the PSC
column4: both of which agencies responded to the OSS failure raised in respondents complaint by imposing fines and other burdens on Verizon.  Against the slight benefits of antitrust intervention here must be weighed a realistic assessment of its costs.  Allegations of violations of 251(c)(3) duties are both technical and extremely numerous
column5: and hence difficult for antitrust courts to evaluate.  Applying 2s requirements to this regime can readily result in false positive mistaken inferences that chill the very conduct the antitrust laws are designed to protect.  Matsushita Elec. Industrial Co. v. Zenith Radio Corp.

column1: 1.This Courts review of Castros claim is not barred by the requirement that the grant or denial of an authorization by a court of appeals to file a second or successive application  shall not be the subject of a [certiorari] petition

column1: 2.A federal court cannot recharacterize a pro se litigants motion as a first 2255 motion unless it first informs the litigant of its intent to recharacterize
column2: warns the litigant that this recharacterization means that any subsequent 2255 motion will be subject to the restrictions on second or successive motions
column3: and provides the litigant an opportunity to withdraw the motion or to amend it so that it contains all the 2255 claims he believes he has.  If these warnings are not given
column4: the motion cannot be considered to have become a 2255 motion for purposes of applying to later motions the laws second or successive restrictions.  Nine Circuits have placed such limits on recharacterization
column5: and no one here contests the lawfulness of this judicially created requirement.  Pp.57.

column1: 3.Because the District Court failed to give the prescribed warnings
column2: Castros 1994 motion cannot be considered a first 2255 motion and his 1997 motion cannot be considered a second or successive one.  The Government argues that Castros failure to appeal the 1994 recharacterization makes the recharacterization valid as a matter of law of the case.  And
column3: according to the Government
column5: the 1997 2255 motion is Castros second
column6: not his first.  This Court disagrees.  The point of a warning is to help the pro se litigant understand not only (1) whether he should withdraw or amend his motion
column7: but also (2) whether he should contest the recharacterization
column8: say
column9: on appeal.  The lack of warning prevents his making an informed judgment as to both.  The failure to appeal simply underscores the practical importance of providing the warning.  Hence
column10: an unwarned recharacterization cannot count as a 2255 motion for purposes of the second or successive provision whether or not the unwarned pro se litigant takes an appeal.  Even assuming that the law of the case doctrine applies here
column11: the doctrine simply expresses common judicial practice; it does not limit the courts power.  Pp.79.

column1: Held:The Ninth Circuit improperly applied a disparate-impact analysis to respondents disparate-treatment claim.  This Court has consistently distinguished between disparate-treatment and disparate-impact claims.  The former arise when an employer treats some people less favorably than others because of a protected characteristic.  Liability depends on whether the protected trait actually motivated the employers action.  The latter involve facially neutral employment practices that fall more harshly on one group than another and cannot be justified by business necessity.  Such practices may be deemed illegally discriminatory without evidence of the employers subjective discrimination.  Both claims are cognizable under the ADA
column2: but courts must be careful to distinguish between the theories.  Here
column3: respondent was limited to the disparate-treatment theory that petitioner refused to rehire him because it regarded him as disabled and/or because of his record of disability.  Petitioners proffer of its neutral no-rehire policy plainly satisfied its obligation under McDonnell Douglas to provide a legitimate
column4: nondiscriminatory reason for refusing to rehire respondent.  Thus
column5: the only remaining question before the Ninth Circuit was whether there was sufficient evidence from which a jury could conclude that petitioner did make its employment decision based on respondents status as disabled despite its proffered explanation.  Instead
column6: that court concluded that
column7: as a matter of law
column8: the policy was not a legitimate
column9: nondiscriminatory reason sufficient to defeat a prima facie case of discrimination.  In doing so
column10: the Ninth Circuit improperly focused on factors that pertain only to disparate-impact claims
column11: and thus ignored the fact that petitioners no-hire policy is a quintessential legitimate
column12: nondiscriminatory reason for refusing to rehire an employee who was terminated for violating workplace conduct rules.  Pp.711.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE SIXTH CIRCUIT
The University of Michigan Law School (Law School)
column2: one of the Nation's top law schools
column3: follows an official admissions policy that seeks to achieve student body diversity through compliance with Regents of Univ. of Cal. v. Bakke
column4: 438 U. S. 265. Focusing on students' academic ability coupled with a flexible assessment of their talents
column5: experiences
column6: and potential
column7: the policy requires admissions officials to evaluate each applicant based on all the information available in the file
column8: including a personal statement
column9: letters of recommendation
column10: an essay describing how the applicant will contribute to Law School life and diversity
column11: and the applicant's undergraduate grade point average (GPA) and Law School Admission Test (LSAT) score. Additionally
column12: officials must look beyond grades and scores to so-called ""soft variables
column13: such as recommenders' enthusiasm
column14: the quality of the undergraduate institution and the applicant's essay
column15: and the areas and difficulty of undergraduate course selection. The policy does not define diversity solely in terms of racial and ethnic status and does not restrict the types of diversity contributions eligible for ""substantial weight
column16: but it does reaffirm the Law School's commitment to diversity with special reference to the inclusion of African-American
column18: and Native-American students
column19: who otherwise might not be represented in the student body in meaningful numbers. By enrolling a ""critical mass"" of underrepresented minority students
column20: the policy seeks to ensure their ability to contribute to the Law School's character and to the legal profession.

column1: When the Law School denied admission to petitioner Grutter

column4: alleging that respondents had discriminated against her on the basis of race in violation of the Fourteenth Amendment
column5: Title VI of the Civil Rights Act of 1964
column6: and 42 U. S. C.  1981; that she was rejected because the Law School uses race as a ""predominant"" factor
column7: giving applicants belonging to certain minority groups a significantly greater chance of admission than students with similar credentials from disfavored racial groups; and that respondents had no compelling interest to justify that use of race. column8: holding that Justice Powell's opinion in Bakke was binding precedent establishing

column1: diversity as a compelling state interest
column2: and that the Law School's use of race was narrowly tailored because race was merely a ""potential 'plus' factor"" and because the Law School's program was virtually identical to the Harvard admissions program described approvingly by Justice Powell and appended to his Bakke opinion.

The Richmond Redevelopment and Housing Authority (RRHA)
column3: owns and operates Whitcomb Court
column5: the Richmond City Council conveyed Whitcomb Court's streets to the RRHA in an effort to combat crime and drug dealing by nonresidents. In accordance with the terms of conveyance
column6: the RRHA enacted a policy authorizing the Richmond police to serve notice on any person lacking ""a legitimate business or social purpose"" for being on the premises and to arrest for trespassing any person who remains or returns after having been so notified. The RRHA gave respondent Hicks
column7: a nonresident
column8: written notice barring him from Whitcomb Court. Subsequently
column9: he trespassed there and was arrested and convicted. At trial
column10: he claimed that RRHA's policy was
column11: among other things
column12: unconstitutionally overbroad. The Virginia Court of Appeals vacated his conviction. In affirming
column13: the Virginia Supreme Court found the policy unconstitutionally overbroad in violation of the First Amendment because an unwritten rule that leafleting and demonstrating require advance permission vested too much discretion in Whitcomb Court's manager.

column1: Held: The RRHA's trespass policy is not facially invalid under the First Amendment's overbreadth doctrine. Pp. 118-124.

column2: a showing that a law punishes a ""substantial"" amount of protected free speech
column3: ""in relation to the statute's plainly legitimate sweep
column7: suffices to invalidate all enforcement of that law ""until and unless a limiting construction or partial invalidation so narrows it as to remove the seeming threat or deterrence to constitutionally protected expression
column8: id.
column9: at 613. Only substantial overbreadth supports such facial invalidation
column10: since there are significant social costs in blocking a law's application to constitutionally unprotected conduct. Pp. 118-120.

column1: (b) This Court has jurisdiction to review the First Amendment merits question here. Virginia's actual injury in fact-the inability to prosecute Hicks for trespass-is sufficiently distinct and palpable to confer Article III standing. pp. 120-121.
(c) Even assuming the invalidity of the ""unwritten"" rule for leafleters and demonstrators
column2: Hicks has not shown that the RRHA policy prohibits a substantial amount of protected speech in relation to its many legit-

column1: imate applications. Both the notice-barment rule and the ""legitimate business or social purpose"" rule apply to all persons entering Whitcomb Court's streets
column2: not just to those seeking to engage in expression. Neither the basis for the barment sanction (a prior trespass) nor its purpose (preventing future trespasses) implicates the First Amendment. An overbreadth challenge rarely succeeds against a law or regulation that is not specifically addressed to speech or conduct necessarily associated with speech. Any applications of the RRHA's policy that violate the First Amendment can be remedied through as-applied litigation. Pp. 121-124.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE EIGHTH CIRCUIT
A Federal Magistrate Judge (Magistrate) initially found petitioner Sell
column2: who has a long history of mental illness
column3: competent to stand trial for fraud and released him on bail
column4: but later revoked bail because Sell's condition had worsened. Sell subsequently asked the Magistrate to reconsider his competence to stand trial for fraud and attempted murder. The Magistrate had him examined at a United States Medical Center for Federal Prisoners (Medical Center)
column5: found him mentally incompetent to stand trial
column6: and ordered his hospitalization to determine whether he would attain the capacity to allow his trial to proceed. While there
column7: Sell refused the staff's recommendation to take antipsychotic medication. Medical Center authorities decided to allow involuntary medication
column8: which Sell challenged in court. The Magistrate authorized forced administration of antipsychotic drugs
column9: finding that Sell was a danger to himself and others
column10: that medication was the only way to render him less dangerous
column11: that any serious side effects could be ameliorated
column12: that the benefits to Sell outweighed the risks
column13: and that the drugs were substantially likely to return Sell to competence. In affirming
column14: the District Court found the Magistrate's dangerousness finding clearly erroneous but concluded that medication was the only viable hope of rendering Sell competent to stand trial and was necessary to serve the Government's interest in obtaining an adjudication of his guilt or innocence. The Eighth Circuit affirmed. Focusing solely on the fraud charges
column15: it found that the Government had an essential interest in bringing Sell to trial
column16: that the treatment was medically appropriate
column17: and that the medical evidence indicated a reasonable probability that Sell would fairly be able to participate in his trial.

column1: 1. The Eighth Circuit had jurisdiction to hear the appeal. The District Court's pretrial order was an appealable ""collateral order"" within the exceptions to the rule that only final judgments are appealable. The order conclusively determines the disputed question whether Sell has a legal right to avoid forced medication. Coopers & Lybrand v. Livesay
column3: 468. It also resolves an important issue
column4: for involuntary medical treatment raises questions of clear constitutional importance. Ibid. And the issue is effectively unreviewable on appeal

column3: since
column5: Sell will have undergone forced medication-the very harm that he seeks to avoid and which cannot be undone by an acquittal. Pp.175-177.

column1: 2. Under the framework of Washington v. Harper
column3: and Riggins v. Nevada
column5: the Constitution permits the Government involuntarily to administer antipsychotic drugs to render a mentally ill defendant competent to stand trial on serious criminal charges if the treatment is medically appropriate
column6: is substantially unlikely to have side effects that may undermine the trial's fairness
column7: and
column8: taking account of less intrusive alternatives
column9: is necessary significantly to further important governmental trial-related interests. Pp. 177-183.

column1: (a) This standard will permit forced medication solely for trial competence purposes in certain instances. But these instances may be rare
column2: because the standard says or fairly implies the following: First
column3: a court must find that important governmental interests are at stake. The Government's interest in bringing to trial an individual accused of a serious crime is important. However
column4: courts must consider each case's facts in evaluating this interest because special circumstances may lessen its importance
column5: e. g.
column6: a defendant's refusal to take drugs may mean lengthy confinement in an institution
column7: which would diminish the risks of freeing without punishment one who has committed a serious crime. In addition to its substantial interest in timely prosecution
column8: the Government has a concomitant interest in assuring a defendant a fair trial. Second
column9: the court must conclude that forced medication will significantly further those concomitant state interests. It must find that medication is substantially likely to render the defendant competent to stand trial and substantially unlikely to have side effects that will interfere significantly with the defendant's ability to assist counsel in conducting a defense. Third
column10: the court must conclude that involuntary medication is necessary to further those interests and find that alternative
column11: less intrusive treatments are unlikely to achieve substantially the same results. Fourth
column12: the court must conclude that administering the drugs is medically appropriate. Pp.177-181.

column1: (b) The court applying these standards is trying to determine whether forced medication is necessary to further the Government's interest in rendering the defendant competent to stand trial. If a court authorizes medication on an alternative ground
column3: the need to consider authorization on trial competence grounds will likely disappear. There are often strong reasons for a court to consider alternative grounds first. For one thing
column4: the inquiry into whether medication is permissible to render an individual nondangerous is usually more objective and manageable than the inquiry into whether medication is permissible to render a defendant competent. For another

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE NINTH CIRCUIT

column3: the minimum price paid to dairy farmers producing raw milk is regulated pursuant to federal marketing orders
column4: which guarantee a uniform price for the producers
column5: but through pooling mechanisms require the processors of different classes of dairy products to pay different prices. California has adopted a similar
column6: although more complex
column7: program to regulate the minimum prices paid by California processors to California producers. Three state statutes create California's milk marketing structure: 1935 and 1967 Acts establish milk pricing and pooling plans
column8: while a 1947 Act governs the composition of milk products sold in the State. Under the state scheme
column9: California processors of fluid milk pay a premium price (part of which goes into a price equalization pool) that is higher than the prices paid to producers. During the 1990's
column10: it became profitable for some California processors to buy raw milk from out-of-state producers. In 1997
column11: the California Department of Food and Agriculture amended its regulations to require contributions to the price equalization pool on some out-ofstate purchases. Petitioners
column12: out-of-state dairy farmers
column13: brought these suits
column14: alleging that the 1997 amendment unconstitutionally discriminates against them. Without reaching the merits
column15: the District Court dismissed both cases. The Ninth Circuit affirmed
column16: holding
column18: that a 1996 federal statute immunized California's milk pricing and pooling laws from Commerce Clause challenge
column19: and that the individual petitioners' Privileges and Immunities Clause claims failed because the 1997 amendment did not
column21: create classifications based on any individual's residency or citizenship.

California ... to effect any law ... regarding ... the percentage of milk solids or solids not fat in fluid milk products sold ... in [that] State ... ; or ... the labeling of such fluid milk products ... "" Section 144 plainly covers California laws regulating the composition and labeling of fluid milk products
column2: but does not mention pricing laws. This Court will not assume that Congress has authorized state regulations that burden or discriminate against interstate commerce unless such an intent is clearly expressed. South-Central Timber Development
column3: Inc. v. Wunnicke
column5: 91. Because  144 does not express such an intent with respect to California's pricing and pooling laws
column6: the Ninth Circuit erred in relying on that section to dismiss petitioners' Commerce Clause challenge. Pp. 64-66.

column1: 2. The Ninth Circuit's rejection of the individual petitioners' Privileges and Immunities Clause claims is inconsistent with Chalker v. Birmingham & Northwestern R. Co.
column4: in which this Court held that the practical effect of a Tennessee tax-which did not on its face draw any distinction based on citizenship or residence
column5: but did impose a higher rate on persons having their principal offices out of State-was discriminatory
column6: given that an individual's chief office is commonly in the State of which he is a citizen. In these cases as well
column7: the absence of an express statement in the California laws and regulations identifying out-of-state residency or citizenship as a basis for disparate treatment is not a sufficient basis for rejecting petitioners' claim. In so holding
column8: this Court expresses no opinion on the merits of that claim. Pp.66-67.

column4: and Franchise Tax Bd. provide the framework for answering the question whether the National Bank Act provides the exclusive cause of action for usury claims against national banks. Section 85 sets substantive limits on the interest rates that national banks may charge
column5: while  86 prescribes the remedies available to borrowers who are charged higher rates and the procedures governing such claims. If the interest charged here did not violate  85 limits

Only if Congress intended  86 to provide the exclusive cause of action for usury claims against national banks would the statute be comparable to the provisions construed in Avco and Metropolitan Life. This Court has long construed the National Bank Act as providing the exclusive federal cause of action for usury against national banks. See

column2: perjury or contempt.''' Michigan v. Tucker

column1: (b) The Ninth Circuit's approach is also irreconcilable with this Court's case law. The government may compel witnesses to testify at trial or before a grand jury
column3: so long as the witness is not the target of the criminal case in which he testifies
column5: e. g.
column6: Kastigar v. United States
column8: 443; and this Court has long permitted the compulsion of incriminating testimony so long as the statements (or evidence derived from them) cannot be used against the speaker in a criminal case
column9: id.

column11: while Martinez likely did not
column12: does not make the immunized witness' statements any less compelled and lends no support to the Ninth Circuit's conclusion that coercive police interrogations alone violate the Fifth Amendment. Moreover
column13: those subjected to coercive interrogations have an automatic protection from the use of their involuntary statements in any subsequent criminal trial

column1: (c) The fact that the Court has permitted the Fifth Amendment privilege to be asserted in noncriminal cases does not alter the conclusion in this case. column2: and the exclusionary rule-are designed to safeguard the core constitutional right protected by the Self-Incrimination Clause. They do not extend the scope of that right itself
column3: just as violations of such rules do not violate a person's constitutional rights. Accordingly
column4: Chavez's failure to read Miranda warnings to Martinez did not violate Martinez's constitutional rights and cannot be grounds for a  1983 action. column1: ON PETITION FOR WRIT OF CERTIORARI TO THE SUPREME COURT OF FLORIDA

Petitioner Bunkley had a pocketknife with a 21h- to 3-inch blade in his pocket when he was arrested as he left an unoccupied restaurant. He was charged with first-degree burglary because his knife was classified as a ""dangerous weapon"" under Florida law
column3: and was sentenced to life in prison. Had the pocketknife not been so classified
column4: his sentence could have been no more than five years. His conviction became final in 1989. Florida has exempted the ""common pocketknife"" from its weapons statute since 1901
column5: and the relevant language has remained unchanged. In 1997
column6: in a separate case
column7: the Florida Supreme Court interpreted the meaning of the ""common pocketknife"" exception for the first time
column8: including a pocketknife with a 3%-inch blade within the exception. L. B. v. State
column10: 373. Bunkley then moved for state postconviction relief
column11: alleging that his armed robbery conviction was invalid under L. B. because his pocketknife was shorter than 3% inches and could not therefore support a conviction involving weapon possession. The Circuit Court denied his motion
column12: and the State District Court of Appeal affirmed. The State Supreme Court rejected Bunkley's claim
column13: holding that L. B. was an evolutionary refinement in the law that did not apply retroactively.

column1: Held: The Florida Supreme Court erred in failing to determine whether the ""common pocketknife"" exception encompassed Bunkley's pocketknife at the time his conviction became final. The result here is controlled by Fiore v. White
column3: which involved a Pennsylvania criminal statute that the Pennsylvania Supreme Court interpreted for the first time after Fiore's conviction had already become final. Under that interpretation
column4: Fiore's conduct did not violate an element of the statute. The Pennsylvania Supreme Court's reply to this Court's certified question-that its interpretation merely clarified the statute's plain language-revealed that Fiore's conviction violated due process
column5: because a State cannot convict a person without proving each element of the crime beyond a reasonable doubt. Application of Fiore's due process principles may render a retroactivity analysis unnecessary here. Fiore requires the Florida Supreme Court to answer whether
column6: in light of L. B.
column7: Bunkley's 2Y2- to 3-inch pocketknife fit within the state statute's ""common pocketknife"" exception at the time his conviction became final.

column1: Because the L. B. decision cast doubt on the validity of Bunkley's conviction by interpreting the exception to cover his weapon
column2: Fiore entitles Bunkley to a determination whether L. B. correctly stated the law as it stood at the time Bunkley was convicted. The Florida Supreme Court characterized L. B. as part of a century-long evolutionary process
column3: but did not decide what stage the law had reached by 1989. The proper question for purposes of Fiore is not just whether the law changed
column4: but when it changed. Unless and until the State Supreme Court clarifies the exception's content in 1989
column5: this Court cannot know whether Bunkley's conviction violates the due process principles set forth in Fiore.

At respondent's trial on an open murder charge

column4: for a directed verdict of acquittal as to first-degree murder. The trial judge stated that second-degree murder was ""'an appropriate charge

S. C.  2254(d)(1). The Sixth Circuit recited this standard but then forgot to apply it
column3: reviewing the double jeopardy question de novo. This was error. A state-court decision is ""contrary to"" this Court's clearly established law if it ""applies a rule that contradicts the governing law set forth in [the Court's] cases"" or if it ""confronts a set of facts that are materially indistinguishable from a decision of this Court and neverthe-

column5: and reaffirmed the principles articulated in
column6: the applicable precedents of United States v. Martin Linen Supply Co.
column8: and Sma lis v. Pennsylvania
column9: 476 U. S. 140. Nowhere did it apply a legal standard contrary to those set forth in this Court's cases
column10: nor did it confront a set of facts materially indistinguishable from those in any case decided by this Court. The state court's decision therefore was not ""contrary to"" this Court's precedents. Nor was the state court's decision an ""unreasonable application"" of clearly established law. That court applied both Martin Linen and Sma lis to conclude that the judge's comments were not sufficiently final to terminate jeopardy. In reaching this conclusion
column11: in addition to reviewing the context and substance of the trial judge's comments at length
column12: the court observed that there was no formal judgment or order entered on the record. While it noted that formal motions or rulings were not required to demonstrate finality as a matter of Michigan law
column13: it cautioned that a judgment must bear sufficient indicia of finality and it concluded that sufficient indicia were not present here. This was not an objectively unreasonable application of clearly established Supreme Court law. Indeed

column15: it was at least reasonable for the state court to conclude otherwise. Pp. 638-643.

The Federal Magistrate Act of 1979 (Act) empowers full-time magistrate judges to conduct ""any or all proceedings in a jury or nonjury civil matter and order the entry of judgment in the case
column2: as long as they are ""specially designated ... by the district court"" and acting with ""the consent of the parties."" 28 U. S. C.  636(c)(1). Respondent Withrow
column3: a state prisoner
column4: brought an action under 42 U. S. C.  1983 against members of the prison's medical staff
column5: petitioners Roell
column6: Garibay
column7: and Reagan
column8: alleging that they had deliberately disregarded his medical needs in violation of the Eighth Amendment. During a preliminary hearing
column9: the Magistrate Judge told Withrow that he could choose to have her rather than the District Judge preside over the entire case. Withrow agreed orally and later in writing
column10: but the petitioners did not at that point give their consent. Without waiting for their decision
column11: the District Judge referred the case to the Magistrate Judge for final disposition
column12: but with the caveat that all petitioners would have an opportunity to consent to her jurisdiction
column13: and that the referral order would be vacated if any of them did not consent. Only Reagan gave written consent to the referral; Roell and Garibay said nothing about the referral. The case nevertheless proceeded in front of the Magistrate Judge
column14: all the way to a jury verdict and judgment for the petitioners. Roell and Garibay voluntarily participated in the entire course of proceedings and voiced no objection when
column16: the Magistrate Judge made it clear that she believed they had consented. When Withrow appealed
column17: the Fifth Circuit sua sponte remanded the case to the District Court to determine whether the parties had consented to proceed before the Magistrate Judge. Only then did Roell and Garibay file a formal letter of consent stating that they consented to all of the prior proceedings before the Magistrate Judge. The District Court referred the Fifth Circuit's enquiry to that same Magistrate Judge
column18: who reported that by their actions Roell and Garibay clearly implied their consent to her jurisdiction
column19: but ruled that she had lacked jurisdiction because
column21: such consent had to be expressly given. The District Court adopted the report and recommendation. The Fifth Circuit affirmed
column22: holding that

Respondent Hyatt's (hereinafter respondent) ""part-year"" 1991 California income-tax return represented that he had ceased to be a California resident and had become a Nevada resident in October 1991
column2: shortly before he received substantial licensing fees. Petitioner California Franchise Tax Board (CFTB) determined that he was a California resident until April 1992

Petitioner Massaro was indicted on federal racketeering charges in connection with a murder. The day before his trial began
column2: prosecutors learned of a bullet allegedly recovered from the car in which the victim's body was found
column3: but did not inform defense counsel until the trial was underway. Defense counsel more than once declined the trial court's offer of a continuance so the bullet could be examined. column4: but did not raise an ineffective-assistance-of-trial-counsel claim. The Second Circuit affirmed. Massaro later moved to vacate his conviction under 28 U. S. C.  2255
column5: claiming
column6: as relevant here
column7: that his trial counsel had rendered ineffective assistance in failing to accept the trial court's offer of a continuance. The District Court found his claim procedurally defaulted because he could have raised it on direct appeal. In affirming
column8: the Second Circuit adhered to its precedent that
column9: when the defendant is represented by new counsel on appeal and the ineffective-assistance claim is based solely on the trial record
column10: the claim must be raised on direct appeal; failure to do so results in procedural default unless the petitioner shows cause and prejudice.

column1: Held: An ineffective-assistance-of-counsel claim may be brought in a collateral proceeding under  2255
column2: whether or not the petitioner could have raised the claim on direct appeal. Requiring a criminal defendant to bring ineffective-assistance claims on direct appeal does not promote the procedural default rule's objectives: conserving judicial resources and respecting the law's important interest in the finality of judgments. Applying that rule to ineffective-assistance claims would create a risk that defendants would feel compelled to raise the issue before there has been an opportunity fully to develop the claim's factual predicate
column3: and would raise the issue for the first time in a forum not best suited to assess those facts
column4: even if the record contains some indication of deficiencies in counsel's performance. A  2255 motion is preferable to direct appeal for deciding an ineffective-assistance claim. When a claim is brought on direct appeal
column5: appellate counsel and the court must proceed on a trial record that is not developed precisely for
column6: and is therefore

column2: the purpose of litigating or preserving the claim. A defendant claiming ineffective counsel must show that counsel's actions were not supported by a reasonable strategy and that the error was prejudicial. Strickland v. Washington
column3: 466 U. S. 668. The evidence introduced at trial
column5: will be devoted to guilt or innocence issues
column6: and the resulting record may not disclose the facts necessary to decide either prong of the Strickland analysis. Under the rule announced here
column7: ineffective-assistance claims ordinarily will be litigated in the first instance in the district court
column8: the forum best suited to developing the facts necessary to determining the adequacy of representation during an entire trial. The court may take testimony from witnesses for the defendant and the prosecution and from the counsel alleged to have rendered the deficient performance. In addition
column9: the  2255 motion often will be ruled upon by the district judge who presided at trial
column10: who should have an advantageous perspective for determining the effectiveness of counsel's conduct and whether any deficiencies were prejudicial. This Court does not hold that ineffectiveassistance claims must be reserved for collateral review
column11: as there may be cases in which trial counsel's ineffectiveness is so apparent from the record that appellate counsel will raise the issue on direct appeal or in which obvious deficiencies in representation will be addressed by an appellate court sua sponte. In such cases
column12: certain questions may arise in subsequent  2255 proceedings concerning the conclusiveness of determinations made on the claims raised on direct appeal; but these implementation matters are not before the Court. pp. 504-509.

S. 377; that it discriminates on the basis of content and viewpoint since it selectively chooses only cross burning because of its distinctive message; and that the prima facie evidence provision renders the statute overbroad because the enhanced probability of prosecution under the statute chills the expression of protected speech.

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR THE ELEVENTH CIRCUIT
Respondent physicians filed suit alleging that managed-health-care organizations
column3: violated
column5: the Racketeer Influenced and Corrupt Organizations Act (RICO) by failing to reimburse them for health-care services that they had provided to patients covered by the organizations' plans. Petitioners moved to compel arbitration. The District Court refused to compel arbitration of the RICO claims on the ground that the arbitration clauses in the parties' agreements prohibited awards of ""punitive damages
column6: and hence an arbitrator lacked authority to award treble damages under RICO. Accordingly
column7: the court deemed the arbitration agreements unenforceable with respect to those claims. The Eleventh Circuit affirmed.

column1: Held: It is unclear whether the agreements actually prevent an arbitrator from awarding treble damages under RICO. This Court's cases have placed different statutory treble damages provisions on different points along the spectrum between purely compensatory and strictly punitive awards. In particular
column2: the Court has repeatedly acknowledged that RICO's treble-damages provision is remedial in nature
column3: and it is not clear that the parties intended the term ""punitive"" to encompass claims for treble damages under RICO. Since the Court does not know how the arbitrator will construe the remedial limitations
column4: the questions whether they render the parties' agreement unenforceable and whether it is for courts or arbitrators to decide enforceability in the first instance are unusually abstract. It would be premature for the Court to address them; the proper course is to compel arbitration. Pp. 403-407.

Amendments made to 28 U. S. C.
column3: by the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA) do not apply to cases pending in federal court on April 24
column5: 521 U. S. 320. Respondent was convicted of first-degree murder and sentenced to death in California state court. Mter his petition for state postconviction relief was denied
column6: he moved for the appointment of federal habeas counsel and a stay of execution in Federal District Court on May 12
column8: and later filed a federal habeas application on July 2
column9: 1996. Although he filed the habeas application after AEDPA's effective date
column10: the District Court concluded
column11: inter alia
column12: that it was not subject to AEDPA because his motions for counsel and a stay were filed prior to that date. The Ninth Circuit agreed that the application was not subject to AEDPA
column13: but reversed for reasons not relevant here.

column1: Held: For purposes of applying the Lindh rule
column2: a case does not become ""pending"" until an actual application for habeas relief is filed in federal court. Respondent's application is subject to AEDPA's amendments because it was not filed until after AEDPA's effective date. Pp. 205-210.

column1: (a) Because of AEDPA's heavy emphasis on the standards governing the review of a habeas application's merits
column2: the Court interprets the Lindh rule in view of that emphasis. Thus
column3: whether AEDPA applies to a state prisoner turns on what was before a federal court on AEDPA's effective date. If
column5: the state prisoner had before a federal court a habeas application seeking an adjudication on the merits of the prisoner's claims
column6: then AEDPA does not apply. Otherwise
column7: an application filed after AEDPA's effective date should be reviewed under AEDPA
column8: even if other filings by that same applicant--e. g.
column9: a request for the appointment of counselor a motion for a stay of execution-were presented to a federal court prior to AEDPA's effective date. A review of the amended chapter 153 supports this conclusion. For example
column10: 28 U. S. C.  2254(e)(1) provides that
column11: ""[i]n a proceeding instituted by an application for a writ of habeas corpus by a person in custody pursuant to the judgment of a State court
column12: a determination of a factual issue made by a State court shall be presumed to be correct."" (Emphasis added.)

column2: that presumption would rarely apply in a capital case
column3: as  2254(e)(I) would be applicable only to those capital prisoners who did not need counsel and did not seek a stay. AEDPA's text
column5: contains no indication that  2254(e)(I) was intended to have such a limited scope. Nor is it reasonable to believe that Congress meant for a capital prisoner to avoid application of  2254(e)(I)'s stringent requirements simply by filing a request for counselor a motion for a stay before filing an actual habeas application. Finally
column6: the procedural rules governing  2254 cases reinforce the Court's view. The Federal Rules of Civil Procedure apply in the habeas context to the extent that they are not inconsistent with the Habeas Corpus Rules. Because nothing in the Habeas Rules contradicts Federal Rule of Civil Procedure 3-""[a] civil action is commenced by filing a complaint""-the logical conclusion is that a habeas suit begins with the filing of a habeas application
column7: the equivalent of a complaint in an ordinary civil case. Pp. 205-208.

column1: (b) As the task here is to apply Lindh to an action under chapter 153
column2: respondent's request to look at provisions in chapter 154 is inapposite. Moreover
column3: his reliance on McFarland v. Scott
column5: which involved the interpretation of  2251
column6: not  2254
column7: and must be understood in light of the Court's concern to protect the right to counsel contained in 18 U. S. C. 848(q)(4)(B)
column8: and Hohn v. United States
column10: which says nothing about whether a request for counselor motion for a stay suffices to create a ""case"" that is ""pending"" within the Lindh rule's meaning
column11: is misplaced. Pp. 208-210.

column3: six former Norfolk employees (asbestosis claimants)
column4: brought this suit in a West Virginia state court under the Federal Employers' Liability Act (FE LA or Act). Section 1 of the FELA provides: ""Every common carrier by railroad while engaging in [interstate commerce]
column5: shall be liable in damages to any person suffering injury while he is employed by such carrier in such commerce ... for such injury ... resulting in whole or in part from the [carrier's] negligence."" As an element of their damages
column6: the asbestosis claimants sought recovery for mental anguish based on their fear of developing cancer. The trial court instructed the jury that a plaintiff who demonstrated a reasonable fear of cancer related to proven physical injury from asbestos was entitled to compensation for that fear as a part of the damages awardable for pain and suffering. The court also instructed the jury not to reduce recoveries because of nonrailroad exposures to asbestos
column7: so long as the jury found that Norfolk was negligent and that dust exposures at Norfolk contributed

column10: which would have (1) ruled out damages for fear of cancer unless the claimant proved both an actual likelihood of developing cancer and physical manifestations of the alleged fear
column11: and (2) required the jury to apportion damages between Norfolk and other employers alleged to have contributed to an asbestosis claimant's disease. The jury returned damages awards for each claimant. The Supreme Court of Appeals of West Virginia denied discretionary review.

column1: SUPREME COURT OF THE UNITED STATES
CONNECTICUT DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC SAFETY  ET AL. v. DOE
column2: INDIVIDUALLY AND ON BEHALF OF ALL  OTHERS SIMILARLY SITUATED

column1: CERTIORARI TO THE UNITED STATES COURT OF APPEALS FOR  THE SECOND CIRCUIT

column2: Connecticut's ""Megan's Law"" requires persons convicted of sexual offenses to register with the Department of Public Safety (DPS) upon their release into the community
column3: and requires DPS to post a sex offender registry containing registrants' names
column5: photographs
column6: and descriptions on an Internet Website and to make the registry available to the public in certain state offices. Respondent Doe (hereinafter respondent)
column7: a convicted sex offender who is subject to the law
column8: filed a 42 U. S. C.  1983 action on behalf of himself and similarly situated sex offenders
column9: claiming that the law violates
column10: inter alia
column11: the Fourteenth Amendment's Due Process Clause. The District Court granted respondent summary judgment
column12: certified a class of individuals subject to the law
column13: and permanently enjoined the law's public disclosure provisions. The Second Circuit affirmed
column14: concluding that such disclosure both deprived registered sex offenders of a ""liberty interest
column15: and violated the Due Process Clause because officials did not afford registrants a predeprivation hearing to determine whether they are likely to be ""currently dangerous.""

column1: Held: The Second Circuit's judgment must be reversed because due process does not require the opportunity to prove a fact that is not material to the State's statutory scheme. Mere injury to reputation

column2: does not constitute the deprivation of a liberty interest. Paul v. Davis
column3: 424 U. S. 693. But even assuming
column5: that respondent has been deprived of a liberty interest
column6: due process does not entitle him to a hearing to establish a fact-that he is not currently dangerousthat is not material under the statute. Cf.
column7: e. g.
column8: Wisconsin v. Constantineau
column9: 400 U. S. 433. As the DPS Website explains
column10: the law's requirements turn on an offender's conviction alone-a fact that a convicted offender has already had a procedurally safeguarded opportunity to contest. Unless respondent can show that the substantive rule of law is defective (by conflicting with the Constitution)
column11: any hearing on current dangerousness is a bootless exercise. Respondent expressly disavows any reliance on the substantive component of the Fourteenth Amendment's protections
column12: and maintains that his challenge is strictly a procedural one. But States are not barred by principles of ""procedural due process"" from drawing such classifications. Michael H. v. Gerald D.
column14: 120 (plurality opinion). Such claims ""must ultimately be analyzed"" in terms of substantive due process. Id.
column15: at 121. Because the question is not properly before the Court
column16: it expresses no opinion as to whether the State's law violates substantive due process principles. Pp.6-8.

column2: any felony can constitute the third strike subjecting a defendant to a prison term of 25 years to life. Because each of his petty theft convictions thus triggered a separate application of the three strikes law
column3: the judge sentenced him to two consecutive terms of 25 years to life. In affirming
column4: the California Court of Appeal rejected his claim that his sentence violated the constitutional prohibition against cruel and unusual punishment. It found the Solem v. Helm
column6: proportionality analysis questionable in light of Harmelin v. Michigan
column7: 501 U. S. 957. It then compared the facts in Andrade's case to those in Rummel v. Estelle
column8: 445 U. S. 263-in which this Court rejected a claim that a life sentence was grossly disproportionate to the felonies that formed the predicate for the sentence
column9: id.

column11: but the Ninth Circuit granted him a certificate of appealability and reversed. Reviewing the case under the Antiterrorism and Effective Death Penalty Act of 1996 (AEDPA)

As part of its effort to improve the safety of the Nation's highways
column2: Congress adopted the Hazard Elimination Program (Program)
column4: which provides state and local governments with funding to improve the most dangerous sections of their roads. To be eligible for such funding
column5: a government must undertake a thorough evaluation of its public roads. Because of States' concerns that the absence of confidentiality with respect to  152's compliance measures would increase the liability risk for accidents that took place at hazardous locations before improvements could be made and Department of Transportation's concerns that the States' reluctance to be forthcoming in their data collection efforts undermined the Program's effectiveness
column6: Congress
column8: adopted 409
column9: which provided that materials ""compiled"" for  152 purposes ""shall not be admitted into evidence in Federal or State court."" Responding to subsequent court decisions holding that  409 did not apply to pretrial discovery and protected only materials that an agency actually generated for  152 purposes
column10: not documents that the agency collected to prepare its  152 application
column11: Congress expressly made the statute applicable to pretrial discovery in 1991 and added the phrase ""or collected"" after the word ""compiled"" in 1995. Several months before respondent Ignacio Guillen's wife died in an automobile accident at an intersection in petitioner county
column12: petitioner's  152 funding request for the intersection was denied. Its second request was approved three weeks after the accident. Petitioner declined to provide respondents' counsel with information about accidents at the intersection
column13: asserting that any relevant information was protected by  409. Respondents then filed an action in Washington state court
column14: alleging that petitioner's refusal to disclose violated the State's Public Disclosure Act (PDA). The trial court granted respondents summary judgment
column15: ordering petitioner to disclose five documents and pay respondents' attorney's fees. While petitioner's appeal was pending
column16: respondents filed another state-court action
column17: alleging that petitioner had been negligent in failing to install proper traffic controls at the intersection. Petitioner refused to comply with their discovery request for information regarding accidents at the intersection
column18: and respondents

column2: consolidated this and the PDA appeals
column3: and in large part affirmed

column5: the Washington Supreme Court determined that disclosure under the relevant state laws would be appropriate only if the requested materials were not protected by  409; that protection under  409
